Sec. 6-201. - Alcoholic and malt beverages. 1. Adoption of state law. The governing authority of the Town of Thunderbolt hereby adopts all laws, rules, and regulations as set forth in the laws of the State of Georgia which relate to the handling or selling of alcohol and malt beverage (Council, 11/14/1984). 2. Application for license for liquor or malt beverage sale. Every person, firm or corporation within the town limits of the Town of Thunderbolt that is engaged hereafter or intending to carry on with anyone or more such business in said Town of Thunderbolt, as aforesaid, shall, before engaging or continuing in said business, file with the town council an application for a permit or license to conduct and carry on such business; said application shall set forth the location of the building where such business is to be conducted, and shall file with his application for license a completely filled out form which will be furnished by the clerk of council known as "Application for Alcoholic Beverage License" or "Application for Malt Beverage License." Said application must be resubmitted each year completely filled out before renewal is granted. License fees shall be those amounts set forth in the "Schedule of fees for other specific business," unless specifically set below (Council, 11/14/1984). 3. Background checks for license applicants and all employees. A. License applicants. Prior to or at the time of initially submitting an application, the applicant for a license or permit issued under the terms of this chapter and the owner of the proposed business, shall submit themselves to the police department for fingerprinting B. Employees . All employees shall within 72 hours after the date of their first work in an establishment covered under the terms of this chapter report to the police department for the purposes of being fingerprinted. The chief of police shall furnish to each qualified employee an identification card with pertinent information thereon relating to the height, weight, hair color, eye color, date of birth, social security number, photograph of the holder of such identification card. A fee in the amount of $10.00 shall be charged for the preparation of such identification card. It shall be the responsibility of the employer to the see that the employees are carrying with them an identification card at all times while they are working. Said identification card will expire on December 31 of each year and the employee must renew said identification card, and said card must, at all times, be in the possession of such person affected hereunder for him to be eligible to engage in such business. Fee for renewal of said identification card each year shall be $10.00. C. Possession of registration card necessary to conduct business. It shall be unlawful for any person to own, operate, or be employed by any wholesale or retail liquor, beer, or wine business requiring a license to conduct any place of business without having a valid registration card signed by the chief of police for the town. D. Notification of termination or transfer of employment. It shall be unlawful for the holder of any bar registration card to fail to notify the chief of police, Town of Thunderbolt, or his representative when transferring from the place of employment requiring a bar registration card under this chapter. (Council, 5/28/1954; 11/14/1984). 4. Issuance of license for alcoholic and malt business. A. Terms . The governing authority thereof shall grant a license or permit hereunder when the same is found to be in the public interest and general welfare of the citizens of the Town of Thunderbolt. All persons, firms or corporations to whom such permit or license shall be issued, shall take such permit or license subject to same being revoked at any time as herein provided; such permit shall not be transferable without the approval of the town council thereof. Permits or licenses so granted shall expire at the end of each calendar year, and may be renewed only in the manner and form as provided in this chapter for the original granting of permits and licenses. B. Indicia of public interest . The mayor and alderman of the Town of Thunderbolt thereof, in determining whether or not any license or permit applied for hereunder shall be granted, shall consider the following standards as indicative or whether or not the granting of said license or permit is in the public interest and general welfare: l. The applicant's reputation, character and mental and physical capacity to conduct a business engaged in the sale of malt beverages; 2. The location for which the license is sought to traffic congestion, general character of neighborhood and the effect such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding property values; 3. The number of licenses previously granted for similar businesses in the trading area of the place for which the license is sought; 4. The proximity of the location of said establishment to schools, churches, libraries and other public buildings in the surrounding area; 5. If applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell malt beverages, whether or not applicant or his establishment has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business; and 6. If applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell malt beverages, the manner in which business was conducted thereunder requiring unusual police observation and inspection including the number and frequency of complaints filed by citizens objecting to the manner of conducting business at said location. (Council, 11/14/1984). 5. Grounds for revocation of permit. The following shall be grounds for revocation of all alcoholic beverage licenses: A. Failure of wholesaler or retailer to pay license or excise taxes. B. Commission of any act in violation of the federal, state or local laws or ordinances which would disqualify a person from obtaining a license. C. Selling or distributing or buying alcoholic beverages on which no local or state tax has been paid. D. Commission of any acts in violation of federal, state or local laws or ordinances or running of a licensed business where such violations frequently or regularly occur so as to cause the chief of police to recommend a revocation of the license. E. The change in any circumstances of any license in such way that had such circumstances existed when the application was filed, a license would not have been granted. F. Any recurrent breaches of the peace, disturbances or altercations occurring on licensed premises or the failure of the licensee or his employee promptly to report to the chief of police any violation of the laws or ordinances governing the licensing and sale of beer, wine or alcoholic beverages of which he has no knowledge. G. Any conduct on the part of the license holder or his employees contrary to the public health, safety or morals of the citizens of Thunderbolt. The misconduct of employees as hereinabove set forth is the direct responsibility of the holder of the license and if the employees engage in the selling of any alcoholic beverages, drugs, drug paraphernalia, or anything that would affect the public health, safety or morals of the citizens of Thunderbolt shall be sufficient grounds to have said licenses immediately suspended and revoked. Upon the recommendation of the designated officers as set forth in this chapter, the license can be immediately suspended and a conviction before the municipal court of said town is not required for the suspension and revocation of said license. H. All establishments duly licenses hereunder shall cooperate with the law enforcement department of the Town of Thunderbolt and all law enforcement officers while in the exercise of their sworn duty. The licensee is responsible for showing that no opprobrious words or actions are directed against any law enforcement officer in the performance of his duties, he must render all aid to said law enforcement officers, and said lair enforcement officers shall have the right to enter said business during the legal operation of said business to ascertain if all rules and regulations governing this chapter are being obeyed, or if he is searching in order to apprehend criminals, then any interference by spoken words or actions shall be sufficient grounds for the immediate suspension and revocation of said license, whether the law enforcement officers of the Town of Thunderbolt, the State of Georgia, the federal government, or Chatham County in the performance of their sworn duty, where they have sufficient reason to believe there is a threat to the public health, safety, welfare or morals of the citizens of Thunderbolt. I. Failure to abide by any of the provisions of any law to which the business, owner, or employees are subject. (Council, 11/14/1984.) 6. Revocation procedures. The procedures which shall be followed in revoking all permits shall be as follows: A. Notice shall be given to the holder of a permit at least five days in advance that the mayor and town council of Thunderbolt will hear a recommendation that the license be revoked, and this notice shall include the specific grounds on which this recommendation to the mayor and town council will be made. B. The clerk of council shall notify the permit holder, and the chief of police as to the time that a recommendation for revocation will be heard. C. The city council; shall hear a recommendation for revocation at one of its regular meetings or at a special meeting where notice bas been given as required herein at which time the holder of said permit and any other interested parties will be heard. D. No permit shall be revoked until a majority of the mayor and town council so decided at the time of or subsequent to the hearing on the recommendation for revocation. (Council, 11/14/1984). 7. Notification of action against licensee. All decision approving, denying, suspending, or revoking the permits or licenses shall be in writing with the reasons therefore stated and shall be mailed or delivered to the applicant (O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2(b)(2)). 8. Subjection to particular regulation . Any person, firm or corporation issued a permit under the provisions of this chapter for the sale of alcoholic or malt beverages shall be subject to the following regulations, where applicable, to-wit: A. Reserved. B. Shall not serve or sell to any intoxicated person. C. Shall not serve or sell to any minor as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23.1. D. No malt beverages provided for in this chapter shall be located so as to violation the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21(a)(1)(B). E. Sales on alcoholic beverages on election days shall be governed by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. (Council, 10/26/1988) F. Shall keep their place of business or establishment sufficiently lighted on the interior and exterior so as to discourage disorderly conduct on the premises; all doors leading into and outside the establishment shall be kept closed, but unlocked for exit from the interior, at all times. G. All establishments duly licensed hereunder must fully comply with all sanitary requirements promulgated by the Chatham County Health Department. Said requirements of the Chatham County Health Department are hereby specifically adopted by reference thereto. H. All musical units or amusement machines installed in any establishments licensed hereunder must be properly registered with the clerk of council. The sounds from said musical instruments or machines shall not exceed the volume so that the decibel (sound level) will not carry beyond the building. No outside speakers or amplifying systems shall be attached on the exterior of the buildings. No live entertainment with musical instruments shall be permitted on the roofs or on the outside of the property of the holder of said licenses without a specific waiver for a specified period of time. Said waiver can only be granted by the town council at a regularly scheduled, or special called meeting for said purpose. I. All transactions conducted on the premises of any establishment licensed hereunder involving the sale or transfer of alcoholic beverages must be for cash or its equivalent. Credit transactions are hereby declared to be illegal. J. All boisterous, noisy and disorderly conduct in any place of business, or other place where the beverages provided for in this chapter are permitted to be sold, is expressly forbidden by this chapter, and every person, firm or corporation conducting any place of business for which a permit or license has been granted and for which the license fee has been paid shall be subject to have the said permit or license revoked, in the manner provided for in this chapter, for permitting any such boisterous, noisy, or disorderly conduct in such place of business. K. The town council reserve the right to promulgate additional regulations or ordinances pertaining to the conduct of the business of selling distilled spirits or alcoholic beverages for beverage purposes by the drink and any person licensed hereunder shall be subject to such additional regulations that may be promulgated from time to time by the town council. (Council, 11/14/1984). 9. Selling hours. A. Non-selling hours. No license holder shall sell distilled spirits, malt beverages, or wine between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on the following days: Monday through Saturday, inclusive, or between the hours of 2:55 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. on Sunday, as well as between the hours of 11:30 p.m. Sunday and 2:00 a.m. Monday. However, holders of special licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of subsections B through G of this Code section, may sell distilled spirits, malt beverages, or wine on Sundays during the hours specified in subsections B through G of this Code section. (Revised 1/11/2012) B. Reserved for future use. C. Definition . For the purpose of this subsection, an "eating establishment" shall mean an establishment which is licensed to sell distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine, and which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross food and beverage sales from the sale of prepared meals or food. D. Sale by drink only. Each dealer licensed under this chapter that is authorized to sell distilled spirits, malt beverages, or wine for consumption by the drink only on the premises in certain eating establishments on Sundays shall continue to be so authorized, all in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7. Each dealer licensed under this chapter for package sales for distilled spirits, malt beverages, or wine that is not an eating establishment shall be allowed to sell on Sundays only between the hours designated by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7(q)(1) as presently constituted or hereinafter amended. (Revised 1/11/2012) E. Multiple places of eating in separate buildings. If more than one eating place is maintained in separate buildings by a firm, a license shall be secured for each such building in which it is proposed to sell drinks on Sunday. F. Application process. An application for the license for the selling of distilled spirits in certain eating establishments on Sundays shall be completed by November 30 of the year preceding the year for which the license is brought and returned to the clerk for approval. Failure to supply all information requested will result in disapproval of the said application and disapproval of the said license. G. Application process. An application for the license for the selling of distilled spirits in certain eating establishments on Sundays shall be completed by November 30 of the year preceding the year for which the license is brought and returned to the clerk of approval. Failure to return the application or failure to supply all information requested will result in disapproval of the said application and disapproval of the said license. H. Affidavit verifying nature of business. An affidavit must be attached to the application for each yearly license setting forth that at least 50 percent of the total annual gross food and beverage sales are derived from the sale of prepared meals or food. Failure to attach such affidavit or failure to comply with the terms of the affidavit will result in disapproval of the said application and disapproval of the said license. 10. Prosecution of violators. For the purposes of prosecution of violators of this article, each and every separate section hereof shall be considered a separate offense (Council, 11/14/84; 02/12/86; 1/08/80). Penalty not to exceed six months incarceration or probation; not to exceed $1,000.00 fine. 11. Other police powers applicable. Police powers as provided for elsewhere both now and the future, for specific enforcement of other state and local laws is applicable for the enforcement of 9-201 through inspection of the premises and records thereof (Council, 02/12/1986). Sec. 6-202. - Alcoholic beverage license fees. Not being covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 through 48-13-26, license fees for alcoholic beverage establishments are set by the council, and are available for review in the office of the town clerk. (Council, November 08, 2006, amended June 13, 2012)
;rn0;0; Formerly Code § 6-111. Sec. 6-203. - Mixed drink excise tax ordinance. To establish a mixed drink excise tax; to provide for the administration of tax; to impose a rate for the tax; to provide for collection of the tax; to provide for late payment penalties and interest; to provide procedures for determining the deficiency of the taxes paid; to establish procedures upon failure to file a return; to provide for procedures in cases of overpayment; to establish procedures for the subsequent purchasers or successors of the business; to allow for legal action to collect delinquent taxes; to provide a procedure for revocation of the town liquor license; to provide a penalty for violations; to repeal conflicting ordinances; to provide for an effective date; and for other purposes. 1. Definitions . For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectfully ascribed to them below except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: A. Distilled spirits or liquor . Any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 24 percent alcohol by volume, including but not limited to all fortified wines. B. Drink . Any alcoholic beverage served for consumption on the premises which may or may not be diluted by any other liquid. C. Due date. From the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. D. Licensee . Any person who holds a license or permit from the Town of Thunderbolt to sell alcoholic beverages by the drink. E. Monthly period. The calendar months of any year. F. Person . An individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or co-operative non-profit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular members, excepting the United States of America, the State of Georgia, and any political subdivision of either thereof upon which the Town of Thunderbolt is without power to impose the tax provided herein. G. Purchase price. The consideration received for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink valued in money, whether received in cash or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature and also the amount for which credit is allowed by licensee to the purchaser, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. H. Purchaser . Any person who orders and gives present or future consideration for any distilled spirits by the drink. I. Tax . The tax imposed by this section. 2. Administration generally. (a) The town administrator or his authorized representative shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy and collection of the tax imposed hereby. (b) The town administrator shall have the authority to make and publish reasonably rules and regulations not inconsistent with the article or other laws of the Town of Thunderbolt and the State of Georgia, or the constitution of this state or the United States for administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of taxes hereunder. (c) Every licensee for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink in the Town of Thunderbolt shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the town administrator may require. (d) The town administrator or designee may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee liable for the tax in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the licensee, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. (e) In administration of the provisions of this article, the town administrator may require the filing of reports by any person having in such person's possession or custody information relating to the sales of distilled spirits which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the town administrator's office when required and shall set forth the price charged for each sale, the date of sale and such other information as the town administrator may require. 3. Imposed: Rate. There is hereby imposed and levied upon every sale of distilled spirits purchased by the drink in the Town of Thunderbolt a tax in the amount of three percent of the purchase price of the drink. 4. Collection due by licensee. Every licensee or his agent is hereby authorized and directed to collect the tax imposed by this article from the purchasers of distilled spirits by the drink sold within his licensed premises. 5. Payment; returns, collection fees: Penalties and interest for late payments. All amounts of such taxes shall be due and payable monthly to the town administrator's office of the Town of Thunderbolt on or before the 20th day of the next succeeding respective monthly period. (a) The remittance of the taxes collected should be on a return including gross receipts from the sale of distilled spirits by the drink, amount of tax collected or due for the related period, and such information as may be required by the town administrator. (b) Payments received after the 20th day of the month shall be assessed a penalty of ten percent of the amount due but not less than $100.00 and interest at a rate of one percent per month or any part thereof. (c) Licensees collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and payment of the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state and uses taxes under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-60. 6. Determination of deficiency amount. (a) If the town administrator is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of tax required to be paid to the Town of Thunderbolt by any licensee he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly period. (b) The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month or fraction thereof from the due date of the taxes. (c) In making a determination, the town administrator's office may offset overpayment, for a period or periods, against any underpayment, for another period or periods against penalties and against the interest on underpayment. The interest on overpayment shall be computed in the same manner set forth in subsection (b) above. (d) If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to negligence or disregard of the rules and regulation, a penalty amount of ten percent shall be added to the deficiency amount. (e) If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to fraud or intent to evade any provisions of this chapter or other authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of 25 percent of the deficiency shall be added to the amount of the deficiency. (f) The town administrator or authorized representative shall give to the licensee written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail: if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the licensee at the address as it appears in the records of the town administrator. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. (g) Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should expire last. 7. Determination upon failure to file return. (a) If any licensee fails to make a return, the town administrator shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink at said licensee's pouring outlet. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into possession of the town administrator's office. Upon the basis of this estimate, the town administrator shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the Town of Thunderbolt, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to ten percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made for one or for more than one period. Written notice shall be given. (b) The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month or fraction thereof from the 20th day of the month that any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. In addition, a penalty of ten percent of the determination, but not less than $100.00 shall be assessed for failure to file a return. 8. Overpayment . If the licensee or person determines that he has overpaid tax, penalty or interest, or paid more than once, which fact has been determined by the town administrator, the licensee will have three years from the date of payment to file a claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the town administrator, the excess amount paid the Town of Thunderbolt may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the persons by whom it was paid or his administrators or executors. 9. Purchasers or successors of business. (a) If any licensee or person liable for any amount under this article sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the town administrator showing that the Town of Thunderbolt has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. (b) If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold from the purchase price as required, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to extent of the purchase price. 10. Legal action to collect. At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected becomes due and payable and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the town administrator may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the Town of Thunderbolt to collect the amount delinquent, together with interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 11. Revocation of license. The failure to pay the above proscribed tax shall render the licensee or person liable therefore subject to revocation of their alcoholic beverage license in accordance with the procedures set forth in the applicable ordinance of the Town of Thunderbolt. 12. Penalty . I. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished pursuant to the applicable ordinance(s) of the Town of Thunderbolt. Any licensee or other person who fails to furnish a supplemental return of other data required by the town administrator or who renders a false or fraudulent return shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be punished as aforesaid. II. Any person who fails to pay any taxes due under this article shall not be permitted to renew his occupational tax certificate or alcoholic beverage license until all said taxes have been paid in full. Editor's note— Formerly Code § 6-112. Sec. 6-204. - Insurer license fees. 1. There is hereby levied for the year 1994 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the Town of Thunderbolt in the amount of $40.00. For each separate business location in excess of one which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the Town of Thunderbolt there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of $14.00. For the purposes of this chapter, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. (Council, 11/10/1993) 2. License fee for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales, offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent or an insurer for insurance said insurer shall pay an additional license fee of $14.00 per location for the year 1992 and for each year thereafter. 3. Insurance agency license fees; independent insurance agencies, brokers, etc. not otherwise licensed. There is hereby levied for the year 1992 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 1 hereof, to be a fee set in accordance with the town's "Schedule of Fees for Other Specific Businesses," for each such location within the Town of Thunderbolt. (Council, 11/13/1991) Editor's note— Formerly Code § 6-202. Sec. 6-205. - Home occupation. 1. Home occupation as defined in article III of the Zoning Ordinance of the Town of Thunderbolt may be permitted in R-1, R-2, R-3 and R-M-H subject to the procedures, restrictions and limitations contained in the ordinance and only after approval by the mayor and council of the Town of Thunderbolt. 2. License . A. Business license. The clerk shall receive the applications for a home occupation business license. Such application shall follow the same forms as required for business licenses but shall include the additional information required by this chapter. B. Application . Applications for a home occupation business license shall be filed by the owner and/or lessee of the dwelling unit upon forms furnished by the town. Said application shall describe and set forth the following: 1. The type and purpose of the business to be conducted within the dwelling. 2. The names of all persons residing within the dwelling. 3. The street address of the property upon which the business is to be located. 4. The square foot area to be utilized by the home occupation. 5. The name and address of the owner of the real property upon which the dwelling is located. 6. Written consent of the owner, or his agent, granting permission for the use of the dwelling for conduct of a home occupation. 7. Names and addresses of all adjoining property owners. 8. A plan for off-street parking for customers. C. Hearing . Provided the application is filed at least ten days prior to the next meeting of the mayor and council, the application will be considered by the mayor and council at the meeting following the filing of the application. If the application is filed within this ten-day period, the application will not be considered until the second regular council meeting following the filing of the application. Not later than five days prior to the meeting of the mayor and council to consider the application, the clerk shall mail the adjoining property owners a notice informing them of the application and time and date said application will be considered. D. Approval . If the mayor and council find, after examining the applicant, application and after public comment, that the applicant meets all requirements, including those hereinafter set forth, it may approve the same. In determining whether to approve an application, the mayor and council may consider the following: 1. Is the business to be conducted a use which is compatible with the surrounding neighborhood. 2. Are there objections by the residents in the affected neighborhood. 3. Is there adequate off-street parking for customers of the proposed home occupation. E. Expiration date. All home occupation business licenses shall expire on December 31 of every calendar year. Renewal applications must be filed at least ten days prior to the regular December town council meeting and shall be processed in the same manner as the initial application. F. Home occupation regulatory fee. In addition to the occupation tax fee set forth in the Code of Ordinances, a holder of a home occupation license shall pay a regulatory fee as set by the mayor and council. (Council, 2/8/1995). G. Suspension, revocation of license. Violation of any provision of this article will be grounds for terminating the license granted by the town to the owner and/or the license of the person or entity operating the home occupation. No license shall be suspended, revoked, or canceled except for due cause as herein defined, and the licensee is granted a public hearing before the mayor and council. The licensee will be given ten days' written notice of the time, place and purpose of the hearing, with a statement of the reason for the suspension, revocation or canceling of such permit and/or license. "Due cause" is the willful and/or continued violation of the provisions of the Code of Ordinances of the Town of Thunderbolt. The termination of the license does not in any way preclude the person or persons alleged to have violated the provisions of this article from being charged with a violation of this chapter or preclude the town from taking any other action authorized by the Code of Ordinances, and/or any action authorized by law. 3. Penalties for violation. Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense in the Municipal Court of Thunderbolt. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 4. Remedies . In case any person attempts to operate a business in violation of the Zoning Ordinance of the Town of Thunderbolt, in addition to other remedies, and after due notice to the appropriate person, issue a citation for violation of the Town Code, requiring the presence of the violator in the Municipal Court of Thunderbolt; or institute injunction or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful conduct or use and/or to correct or abate such violation. 5. Reserved . Editor's note— Formerly Code § 5-203. 6. Reserved . 7. Reserved. (Council, 3/9/1994) Secs. 6-206—6-210. - Reserved. Sec. 6-211. - Reserved. (Council 5/11/1988) Editor's note— Section 6-611 has been relocated to be Code § 9-110. Sec. 6-212. - Garage sales. 1. No person may conduct a garage sale within the town without first depositing with the town clerk a refundable deposit of $25.00 and completing an informational form setting forth the name of party conducting the sale, the date and hours of the sale, the address of the property where the sale is to occur. After the date of the sale, upon the applicant filing an affidavit that all signs posted in connection with the garage sale have removed and properly discarded, the clerk shall return to applicant the deposit. 2. No person may conduct a garage sale except: A. Fridays between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m.; B. On Saturdays between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m.; and, C. On Sundays between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. 3. Any person who conducts a garage sale must remove all signs posted in connection with the garage sale not later than 9:00 a.m. on the Monday following the garage sale. 4. Any person who violates subsections A, B or C above or who makes a false affidavit may be subject to a fine not in excess of $500.00 or incarcerated not in excess of ten days.(Council, 4/13/1994) Sec. 6-213. - Town parks and facilities. (Council, 9/10/08) Editor's note— Section 6-213 has been relocated to be Code § 9-111. Secs. 6-214—6-225. - Reserved.

div.p:
ARTICLE I. - AUTHORITY
Sec. 7-101. - Reserved.(Charter, § 10 e(9)). ARTICLE II. - FRANCHISE GRANTS

div.head: Chapter 8 - MUNICIPAL COURT
div.p: Sec. 8-101. - Reserved (Charter § 30(a) and (b), amended 4/5/1995) Sec. 8-102. - Reserved. (Charter § 30(a), amended 4/5/1995)). Sec. 8-103. - Time of court. Court shall be convened on the first and third Thursdays of each month or at other such times as deemed necessary to keep the dockets current. Sec. 8-104. - Reserved. Sec. 8-105. - Service of summons. Any person charged with violation of any town ordinance shall receive notice by service of a summons as herein provided. such summons may be issued by the court clerk, the construction inspectors, or any police officer of the town. The summons shall be directed to the accused and shall distinctly state the offense charged, the time and place, as far as practicable, of the occurrence of the infraction and the day, hour, and place of trial, requiring the accused to appear before the judge of the municipal court to answer the accusation made. Service of the summons shall be made by a police officer or the code enforcement officer of the town either by serving the accused personally or by leaving a copy at his most notorious place of abode, except that in the case of a summons issued for violation of laws or ordinances relating to the parking of motor vehicles, such summons may be directed to an unknown person such as the owner of an automobile designated in the summons and may be served upon such person by leaving a copy in or attached to such automobile. Sec. 8-106. - Reserved. Sec. 8-107. - Failure to obey summons. Any person who fails to appear at the time and place set out in any summons served upon him shall be guilty of contempt of court and upon conviction thereof shall be punished for same. Sec. 8-108. - Arrest and bond. When a police officer has arrested any person for violation of any provision of this Code or any municipal ordinance and a trial cannot be had immediately, the officer may take a cash bond or security bond which adequately secures the appearance of such person for trials. If such person fails or refuses to give a bond, the officer may confine him or her in the town or county jail until a trial can be held, provided that the mayor in his discretion, may release such person on his own recognizance without security. Sec. 8-109. - Forfeiture of bond. Upon the failure of a person to appear in the municipal court at the time and place fixed by the summons, the judge of said court shall enter a judgment of forfeiture on any cash bond, or, in the case of a security bond, shall pass a rule requiring the principal and surety on such bond to show cause on the date named therein which date shall not be less than ten days from the passage of such ruling, why they should not be required to pay the amount of said bond. If no sufficient cause is shown, the judge shall enter judgment against the principal and surety for the amount of the forfeited bond and shall direct the town clerk to issue execution thereon. Sec. 8-110. - Penalties. The judge shall impose no more than six months imprisonment or probation or no more than $1,000.00 in fines or any combination thereof for any single ordinance violation. Said authority shall match what is designated by Georgia law for penalty imposition by a municipal court judge. Sec. 8-111. - Costs. Costs which may be charged against a defendant may include fees to defray costs of operation as established by council and fees from a uniform scale established by council to cover the costs of the clerk and police of Thunderbolt, all services in the arrest and prosecution of offenders in the municipal court, and for the issuance and collection of executions into the town treasury. The town shall also be entitled to reimbursement of the cost, meals, transportation, and care-taking of prisoners bound over to the superior court for violations of state law. Sec. 8-112. - Appeal from municipal judgment. A. Initial appeal . Any person, firm or corporation who may be convicted before the municipal court of the Town of Thunderbolt shall have the right to appeal from the judgment of said court to the council of the Town of Thunderbolt. The council of the Town of Thunderbolt shall try all appeals de novo, and may, in its judgment, confirm the judgment of the municipal court judge, reduce or increase the punishment, or discharge the defendant, provided, however, that the defendant shall not be discharged from custody until he shall have given a bond to be fixed and approved by the court, conditioned to appear and abide the final judgment, sentence or decree in said case. Such bond shall be estimated in the manner provided by law for estreating certiorari bonds in police court. Such appeals shall be made in writing and filed with the clerk within four days after judgment rendered (Sundays and legal holidays excluded). B. Appeal from decision of town council. Reserved (Charter § 30(g) and Council, 2/12/1959 for § 8-112 A and B). Sec. 8-113. - Reserved. Sec. 8-114. - Record of cases. A record of all cases heard in the municipal court for violation of this code or other municipal ordinances shall be recorded on a computer by the court clerk. Such record shall contain: 1. The name of the defendant; 2. The nature of the offense charged; 3. The final disposition of the case; and 4. The date of the final disposition. (Charter § 30; Council, 02/12/1986 or as otherwise indicated).

div.head: Chapter 9 - GENERAL OFFENSES
div.p: Sec. 9-101. - Disorderly conduct, general. Disorderly conduct shall be as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39. (Council, 11/17/1954). Sec. 9-102. - Additional specific acts constituting disorderly conduct. 1. Reserved (Council, 11/17/1954). 2. Public drinking of intoxicants. Drinking intoxicants in vehicles or other places in open view of the public (Council, 11/17/1954 and as presently amended). 3. Public sleeping while intoxicated. Sleeping on the streets or lanes in open public or in parked vehicles while under the influence of intoxicants or other drugs (Council, 11/17/1954 and as presently amended). 4. Reserved. (Council, 11/17/1954). 5. Reserved. (Council, 12/13/1956 and as presently amended). 6. Reserved. (Council, 02/12/1986). 7. Reserved. (Council, 11/17/1954). 8. Reserved. (Council, 11/17/1954). 9. Loud music from residence, which can be heard outside residence or vehicle at a distance of 100 feet from the source of music. 10. Public urination/defecation by anyone. 11. Reserved. Sec. 9-103. - Discharging firearms or other weapons. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm or weapon within or into the town limits unless he is exercising a legal right of security or fulfilling his duties of public office (State reference: O.C.G.A. §§ 16-11-103 through 16-11-105; council as presently amended). Sec. 9-104. - Throwing of missiles. It shall be unlawful for any person in the town to throw any stone, rock, or other missile upon or at any vehicle, building, tree, or other public or private property, or upon at any person in any person in any public or private way or place (Council, 02/12/1986). Sec. 9-105. - Reserved. (Council, 02/12/1986). Sec. 9-106. - Reserved. (Council, 02/12/1986). Sec. 9-107. - Prohibition of possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages in public, parks. 1. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or consume alcoholic beverages in the public parks of the Town of Thunderbolt except for the two waterfront parks in the Town of Thunderbolt presently known W.E. Honey Park and John J. Thomson Park or in any other park on a specific occasion for which the use of a park has been granted to a specific individual or organization for a specific function and for which the Town of Thunderbolt has given express permission for the consumption of alcohol for such function. Any person or organization wishing to use the park for a specific function must obtain a permit from the Town of Thunderbolt for such function and must specifically request, if desired, that alcohol be allowed to be possessed and consumed for such function. The Town of Thunderbolt shall consider such request and make all reasonable effort to grant such request provided that the Town of Thunderbolt has reasonable assurance based upon the information supplied in the request that the function and the possession and consumption of alcohol during such function will not breach the peace. 2. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, the possession and consumption of alcohol in any public parks in the Town of Thunderbolt including the two waterfront parks referred to hereinabove shall not be allowed in glass containers or any other container which if broken might cause a hazard to the safety of individuals using the parks. (Council, 7/9/1997) Sec. 9-108. - Misdemeanor offenses. Every offense which is defined by the Official Code of Georgia (O.C.G.A.) as a crime thereunder and is punishable as a misdemeanor shall be and the same are hereby adopted as penal ordinances by the Town of Thunderbolt. (Ord. 5/9/2001) Sec. 9-109. - Curfew. 1. Definitions . A. As used in this chapter, the term: (1) Child means any person under 17 years of age. (2) Loiter means to sit, stand, or otherwise remain or linger idly at, on or near a public place. (3) Parent means the natural parent or parents, guardian, or other person having the legal care, custody, or control of a child. (4) Public place means any public road, street, or highway or any private street or other area for the passage of automobiles which is open to the public; public or private areas open to the public which are used or intended to be used for the parking of automobiles; the grounds of public school buildings; public parks, playgrounds, athletic fields, or other public recreational areas; or other public or private places located outdoors which are open to the public. B. No parent shall knowingly allow a child for whom the parent is responsible to loiter between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to apply to any child who is: (1) On an errand at the direction of the child's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; (2) In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; (3) Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; (4) On the sidewalk abutting the child's residence or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the police department about the child's presence; (5) Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the town, county, school district, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the child, or going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the town, county, school district, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; (6) Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or (7) Married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with law. (8) Involved in an emergency. As used herein the term "emergency" means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life; C. Any person convicted of violating the provisions of subsection (B) of this section shall be punished as follows: (1) First offense: A fine of not more than $100.00; and (2) Second or subsequent offense: A fine of not more than $300.00. D. In lieu of assessing a fine under subsection (C) of this section, the court may require the person to undergo counseling designed to inform such person of the importance of a proper home environment and close supervision of minor children. (Council, 7/13/1988) Sec. 9-110. - Parades. 1. Definitions . The following words, where used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, shall be deemed to have the following meanings: (1) Administrator . The town administrator shall be the administrator for the receipt and processing of applications for a permit for a private organization or group of private persons to hold a parade, assembly, demonstration, road closing, or other use of public property and roads for private purposes. The town administrator may be assisted by other employees of the Town of Thunderbolt. (2) Private organization or group of private persons. A private organization or group of persons shall be any firm, partnership, corporation, association, or group of individuals more than three in number, or their representatives, acting as a unit. (3) Private purpose. A private purpose shall be any purpose not commanded or directed by statute, ordinance, or other regulation to be performed by the state, county, or other governmental entity. 2. Permit required . Every private organization or group of private persons who wishes to use public property or public roads within the municipal limits of Thunderbolt, Georgia, for private purposes in holding a parade, assembly, demonstration, road closing, or other activity, is hereby required to have a permit from the town for the privilege of engaging in any such activity within the town, unless such a permit is prohibited under state law or the activity is otherwise exempted by law, ordinance, or other valid regulation. 3. Application fee. Every private organization or group of private persons required to procure a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall submit an application for the permit to the administrator, which application shall conform to the requirements of this section in addition to any other provisions of this chapter. (1) Unless otherwise provided herein, each application shall be a written statement upon forms provided by the administrator and submitted within a reasonable time prior to the planned activity, for security checks, verifications, and arrangements to be made, the administrator to act within ten days of the receipt of the completed application. (2) Each application shall contain the following information: (a) Name and home address of the applicant if an individual, or home office address if a corporation or partnership, and telephone where applicant may be contacted; (b) Date, time, and place where the proposed activity is to be carried on, including proposed routes of passage of parades or other proceedings; (c) Kind and class of activity to be carried on; (d) Names and home addresses of the partners, if a partnership; (e) Names and home addresses of the officers and directors, if a corporation; (f) Any additional information which the administrator may find reasonably necessary to the fair administration of this chapter, which may include a complete record of all arrests and convictions against the applicant and every partner, officer, or director of the applicant for violations of any and all laws and ordinances of the town, county, state or federal government, other than minor traffic violations. (3) Each application shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant if an individual, or by a partner if a partnership, or by an officer if a corporation. (4) All information furnished or secured under the authority of this chapter shall be kept in strict confidence by the Town of Thunderbolt; shall not be subject to public inspection; and shall be utilized by the officers of the town responsible for administering the provisions of this chapter. (5) False statements in any application for a license shall be grounds for immediate revocation of the permit, denial of the application and/or denial of future applications. (6) Any application, permit, and registration fees, as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council required under this chapter, shall accompany this application. 4. Administration of ordinance. The administrator, shall administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter for the application for and issuance of permits under this chapter. 5. Duties of administrator. The administrator, or an authorized representative, shall have, among others, the following duties: (1) To prepare and provide the necessary forms for the application for a permit and for the submission of any required information as may be necessary to properly administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. (2) To review the application for completeness, collect whatever fee may be required; to designate or coordinate sites and set time schedules; to coordinate with the Chatham County authorities on all matters concerning said activities; and, where appropriate, to receive the approval of the department of transportation, state highway patrol, town police chief, and the sheriff, or any other necessary public officer, for the requested, activity. (3) To issue to the private organization or group of private persons a permit within ten days of such approval. The administrator may, however, where he deems it appropriate, defer the issuance of a permit until the application for the same shall have been approved by the mayor and council. 6. Procedure for issuance. (a) When this chapter provides for the review of an application for a permit by a town officer designated therein, the administrator shall forward a copy of the application to that officer. The officer charged with the duty of reviewing the application shall make a recommendation thereon, favorable or otherwise, and shall return the recommendation to the administrator after receiving a copy of the application. (b) Upon the receipt of the recommendation of the reviewing officer as hereinabove provided, or upon the receipt of the application if no reviewing officer is designated, the administrator shall take action upon the recommendation and application, although he may refer the same to the mayor and council for consideration and action at its next public meeting. (c) Unless some significant interference with the rights of non-participant citizens exists, or the orderly flow of traffic would be obstructed unreasonably, or a clear and present endangerment to the citizens of the Town of Thunderbolt, or there be other unreasonable interference with the public welfare, peace, safety, health, good order, and convenience of the general public, the permit shall be granted. (d) Where more than one permit is sought for the same date or where the proposed route would result in interference as described in 6(c), the administrator shall have authority to designate reasonable sites and/or routes and set time schedules for the beginning and ending of the activity. The administrator shall have authority to cancel the permit where the activity fails to begin within a reasonable time after the time set for it to begin based on other activities for which permits have been granted or based on the unreasonable interference caused by such delay with the public welfare, peace, safety, health, good order, and convenience to the general public. (e) The administrator shall then issue a permit to the applicant, which permit shall state the nature of the activity authorized and bear the date of issuance and the signature of the administrator. (f) Any applicant whose application for a permit under the ordinance is denied by the administrator may appeal such denial to the Mayor and Council of the Town of Thunderbolt, which shall consider such appeal at the regularly scheduled meeting next following the receipt of the applicant's appeal. (g) The mayor and council shall consider the appeal by requiring the administrator to explain why the permit was denied. Unless the administrator can show significant interference with the rights of non-participating citizens; unreasonable obstruction of the orderly flow of traffic; a clear and present endangerment to citizens of the Town of Thunderbolt; other specific unreasonable interference with the public welfare, peace, safety, health, good order, and convenience of the general public; or failure to comply with the dictates of this chapter, the permit shall be granted. (h) In no event shall any private organization or group of private persons be permitted to bring signs, banners, posters, leaflets, handbills, or any other printed material of any size or shape containing any message intended to influence any judge, juror, witness, or other officer in the discharge of his duty at the Town Hall of the Town of Thunderbolt and the grounds upon which it stands. Further, no private organization or group of private persons may use the roads immediately adjacent to and those roads which lead directly to the Town of Thunderbolt Town Hall grounds for private purposes of holding a parade, assembly, demonstration, or other similar activity on any non-holiday weekday prior to 8:00 a.m. or after 5:00 p.m. or on any Saturday, Sunday, or public holiday prior to 1:00 p.m. or after 5:00 p.m. 7. Violations and penalties. (a) Criminal offenses. (1) Violation of ordinance. Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be amenable to the processes of the Municipal Court of the Town of Thunderbolt. (2) Punishment for violations. Any person or organization convicted of a misdemeanor for the violation of the terms of this chapter shall be punished by fine not to exceed $1,000.00, at the discretion of the Municipal Court of Thunderbolt. (b) Civil penalties. Any person, being an officer or employee of the Town of Thunderbolt, who shall violate any provision of this chapter may be discharged from public service or employment or be subjected to such other disciplinary action as may be appropriate. 8. Defense to prosecution. It shall not be a defense to any prosecution under this chapter for failure to obtain a permit before engaging in any activity described in this chapter that a permit has in fact been issued unless, at his trial, the accused produces in court a valid permit or a certified copy thereof. 9. Reserved. 10. Deposits and financial responsibility. (a) Nothing in this chapter shall relieve any person or persons or organization from responsibility for any injuries or damages to persons or property, private or public, occasioned by their acts or omissions arising from the activity for which any permit under this chapter was issued. (b) After examining the application for a permit and receiving the advice and assistance of any other officer named herein, the administrator, after consideration of the facts reported in the application and any such advice and assistance from another public officer as herein provided, including prior experiences involving the same or similar activity, may require, as a condition precedent to the issuance of the permit, that a fee be paid in an amount reasonably necessary to provide for, among other things, cleanup after the event, special first aid or medical resources, security for vehicles at any staging area, special traffic considerations, temporary toilet facilities, and similar special and extraordinary expenses occasioned by the permitted activity. This amount shall not exceed $500.00. (c) As a condition to issuing a permit, the administrator may require the private organization or group of private persons to provide personnel for trash cleanup of affected areas littered during the activity for which a permit is sought, the provision of first aid and medical resources if considered necessary by the administrator, proof of sufficient storage areas for a large influx of motor vehicles occasioned by the permitted activity, provision of temporary toilet facilities and other similar special and extraordinary items considered to be necessary for the permitted activity in the opinion of the administrator, based on his past experience with such activities and his coordination with other county, city and state officials. In no event shall the administrator require private organizations or groups of private persons to provide personnel for normal governmental functions, such as traffic control and police protection. If additional requirements are placed on private organizations or groups of private persons in accordance with this subparagraph, and those requirements are not met despite assurances by said private organizations or group of private persons, then said failure to comply with the aforementioned requirements shall be grounds for denial of any subsequent permit requested by said private organization or group of private persons and for any other claims for funds expended by the Town of Thunderbolt for those extraordinary expenses agreed to but not provided by the applicant. (d) If the private organization be other than individuals, a permit will not issue without the making of the necessary deposit; individuals may be excused from such a deposit on account of indigence upon the execution under oath by the individual applicant, or by each individual in a group applying for the permit, of a pauper's affidavit. Prior to the receipt of such an affidavit, the administrator shall advise the applicant orally or in writing of the penalties for the execution of a false document. 11. Reserved . 12. Other laws. Any ordinance or law which may be applicable hereto and aid in carrying out and making effective the intent, purpose, and provisions hereof, which shall be literally construed to be in favor of the Town of Thunderbolt, is hereby adopted as a part hereof. (Council 5/11/1988) Editor's note— Formerly Code § 6-211. Sec. 9-111. - Town parks and facilities. 1. Any department of the Town of Thunderbolt or any association affiliated with the Town of Thunderbolt may use any town facility or park for the use of special events or special activities and such department of the town or association affiliated with the town shall be excused from any and all permit fees required pursuant to fees adopted by the Town of Thunderbolt for the use of such parks or facilities. The department head or director of any affiliated association shall be required, however, to fill out and submit an application for the use of the town park or facility. (Council, 9/10/08) Editor's note— Formerly Code § 6-213.

div.head: Chapter 10 - NUISANCES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - OPEN BURNING
Sec. 10-101. - Permit. 1. A permit shall be obtained from the local Georgia Forestry Commission Office and the Thunderbolt Fire Enforcement Officer (fire chief or his designee) for all burning of natural vegetation that is hand or machine piled, including leaf piles on the premises that they fall upon, and vegetative debris disposal from storm damage, weed abatement, disease and/or pest prevention or conducting an area burn. 2. It is unlawful to burn manmade materials such as tires, shingles, plastic, lumber, or household garbage. Permits are issued only for natural vegetative materials. 3. Burning permits are good only for the day issued. If a permit is obtained after dark, the permit will be good for the following day. 4. Notification to the Thunderbolt Fire Department shall be made by the permit holder prior to conducting any open burning within the Town of Thunderbolt. No open burning shall be conducted on days when in the opinion of the fire chief the fire danger or fire danger forecast is considered to be too dangerous. 5. When open burning creates or adds to a hazardous condition, unsafe because of atmospheric conditions, or required permits for open burning have not been obtained, the fire chief or his designee shall be authorized to administer a must comply extinguishment order of the open burning operation by the owner, occupant, or other person responsible for the burning operation. Fines set forth on a schedule in the fire chief's and town administrator's office shall be administered for non-compliance of any such order or other violation of this section of the fire ordinance. Editor's note— Formerly § 5-204(4). Sec. 10-102. - Reserved. (Council, 02/12/1986). (Revised 03/14/2007). Sec. 10-103. - Penalty for violation of § 10-101. Breach of section 10-101 are punishable by a maximum fine of: $100.00 First offense $200.00 Second offense $500.00 Third offense or thereafter. Sec. 10-104. - False alarm ordinance. 1. Definitions . For the purposes of this chapter, the terms herein shall be defined as follows: a) Reserved for future use. b) Alarm system business means any person, partnership or corporation engaging in the business of planning, installing, servicing, maintaining, repairing, replacing, or monitoring alarms systems in the Town of Thunderbolt. c) Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard to which the Town of Thunderbolt Police Department or Town of Thunderbolt Fire Department is expected to respond. d) Alarm system coordinator refers to the public safety director or fire chief or their designees. e) False alarm means a bell, mechanical, electrical, or telephone apparatus, or combination thereof which is activated or the purpose of summoning the Thunderbolt Police Department or Thunderbolt Fire Department to respond to a hold-up, break-in, burglary, unauthorized entry, destruction of property, fire, or other event to which police or fire personnel response are expected to respond when no evidence of such hazards are found and the responding service is not needed. Exceptions will be made for alarms activated during system repairs or maintenance, provided there is prior notification. Exceptions will also be made for false alarms occurring during tornadoes or hurricanes and during widespread power outages exceeding three hours in duration. Such exceptions will not be counted as false alarms. f) Reserved for future use. 2. Reserved. 3. Alarm system service fees/monitoring. A. Fees established. The following service fees are hereby established to discourage excessive false alarms at any single location, enhance the safety of officers of the Town of Thunderbolt Police and Fire Departments, protect the lives and property of the officers of Thunderbolt, reduce unnecessary use of public safety resources, and produce revenues to defray a portion of the costs of responses to false alarms. B. False alarm fees for alarm customer of an alarm system business. Excessive false alarms for alarm customers are considered to be any number in excess of three false alarms during a calendar year. Upon the fourth false alarm, the alarm user will be assessed and billed a fee as set forth on a fee schedule maintained by the public safety director and the town administrator's office for the excessive false alarms. C. Notices, billing and payment of fees. A notice will be sent to the alarm user advising of each occurrence of a false alarm after the second and subsequent false alarm in any calendar year. The alarm user will be fined for each additional false alarm after the third false alarm in that calendar year per the schedule attached to the notice. A notice and invoice will be mailed to the alarm user for each false alarm occurring after the third false alarm in any calendar year. Payment shall be due to the town within 30 days of the invoice date. All fees for excessive false alarms shall also be billed to the property owner if the property is not occupied by the owner. If the person responsible for the false alarm has not paid the fee within 60 days of the date of the invoice from the town, the owner will be responsible for payment of any unpaid false alarm fees. Any owner of the property that becomes responsible for payment of the false alarm fee shall make payment with 90 days of the first billing sent to the responsible person for the false alarm fee. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, all fees for false alarm responses caused by failure of an alarm system business to notify the police or fire department in advance of performing maintenance to an alarm system will be billed to the alarm system business. All such false alarms will be billed as set forth on a fee schedule maintained by the public safety director's and the town administrator's office. Any fees for false alarms pursuant to this paragraph shall be billed to the alarm system business on a monthly basis. a. Excessive false alarms deemed to be a nuisance. False alarms in excess of ten in a billing cycle will be deemed a nuisance and shall subject the offender to penalties as provided by other applicable ordinances of the Town of Thunderbolt. b. Monitoring . The fire and police departments are responsible for monitoring and documenting false alarm incidents. A listing of alarm companies with excessive false alarms, locations with excessive false alarms, and the number of excessive false alarms will be maintained by the alarm systems coordinator. c. The police chief may at his discretion identify those critical or high risk locations that are not subject to automatic suspension for false alarms when such suspension would be detrimental to the safety of the public. Editor's note— Formerly Code § 5-206. ARTICLE II. - DUMPING
Sec. 10-201. - Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, firm, or corporation to throw or dump any trash, tin cans or garbage of any kind in or on the streets, roads or highways or the right-of-way of said streets, roads, or highways in the Town of Thunderbolt or on any property in the Town of Thunderbolt of any person, firm or corporation (Council, 11/17/1954). Sec. 10-202. - Variance. Written permission of the owner of the land where the conduct is taking place and the permission of the chief of police in the form of a permit variance where the public health or comfort is not adversely affected will excuse the conduct. (Enabling legislation: O.C.G.A. § 16-7-48; Council, 11/17/1954 and 02/12/1986). Sec. 10-203. - Penalty. Breach of sections 10-201 and 10-202 are punishable by a maximum fine of: $100.00 First offense $200.00 Second offense $500.00 Third offense or thereafter. ARTICLE III. - NATURAL DEBRIS FAVORABLE TO FIRE OR MOSQUITOES
Sec. 10-301. - Prohibited. 1. It shall be the duty of every owner of any lot, tract or parcel of land within the corporate limits of the Town of Thunderbolt to cut and remove any weeds or grass undergrowth or underbrush, rank vegetation and other debris which will endanger the public health and safety, or will allow stagnant waters to remain upon said premises to breed mosquitoes or to create a fire or health hazard to the inhabitants of the Town of Thunderbolt. 2. Enforcement of this article shall be as set forth in article VIII of this chapter. 3. If the Town of Thunderbolt is not notified, in writing, through its administrative office, that the lot or lots are cleared, then there shall be assessed to each lot owner, an administrative fee of $165.00 plus the cost for cutting and/or removal of debris. (Ord. 2/10/1993, revised 01/09/2008.) ARTICLE IV. - VEHICLES AND JUNK
Sec. 10-401. - Prohibited. 1. No wrecked, junked, or disabled motor vehicle of any kind or description or other junk shall be stored, kept or allowed to remain on any real property, and the failure to have a current license tag on said vehicle shall be prima facie evidence of it being disabled, wrecked or junked, unless the vehicle or junk is maintained or kept within the confines of an enclosed building on said premises not in violation of the zoning ordinance or unless the zoning ordinance permits the maintenance of a junkyard, repair garage, or other maintenance establishment on the premises which has a proper town license for that purpose (Council, 6/13/1973; 02/12/1986). 2. No wrecked, junked or disabled motor boat or motor boat trailer of any kind or description shall be stored, kept, or allowed to remain on any real property. The failure to have a current license tag of the boat trailer or current license number on the boat shall be prima facie evidence of it being disabled, wrecked or junked, unless the boat and/or boat trailer is maintained or kept within the confines of an enclosed building on said premises not in violation of the zoning ordinance or unless the zoning ordinance permits the repair, or other work on boats or boat trailers, and the owner, or tenant, of such premises has a proper town license for operating such a business. (Council 3/12/2014) Sec. 10-402. - Enforcement. Enforcement of this article shall be as set forth in article VIII of this chapter. In addition to the notification procedure as set forth in article VIII of this chapter the police chief or clerk or other officer of the town designated by the mayor and council shall post a notice on the vehicle or junk in violation of this chapter directing the removal of such vehicle or junk. Revised 01/09/2008. ARTICLE V. - NOISE
Sec. 10-501. - Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully make, continue or cause to be made or continued any excessive, unnecessary, or unusually loud noise which disturbs the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of normal sensitivity residing within the town limits (Council, 02/12/1986). Sec. 10-502. - Specific noises prohibited. The following acts are declared to be loud, disturbing, and unnecessary noises in violation of this chapter. 1. Motor vehicle horns. The sounding of any horn on any automobile, motorcycle, or other motor vehicle on any street or public place of the town except as a warning signal. 2. Radios, television sets, and similar devices. The using, operating, or permitting to be played, used or operated, any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, television set, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of neighboring residents. 3. Loudspeakers and amplifiers. The using or operating of any loudspeaker or sound-amplifying device mounted upon any vehicle within the town for the purpose of broadcasting or advertising any information about any business or activity for any other purpose, unless a permit for such sound amplification has been obtained from the mayor or chief of police. 4. Construction equipment and activity. The operating of any equipment or the performing of any outside construction or repair work on buildings, structures, roads, or projects within the town between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. unless a permit for such construction or repair work between such hours has been obtained from the mayor or chief of police. 5. Exhausts . The discharging into the open air of the exhaust of any internal combustion engine, motor boat, or motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 6. Animals and birds . The keeping of any animal or bird which by frequent or continuous barking, chirping, or other types of sound disturbs the comfort or repose of the residents of any residential neighborhood. 7. Vehicle repair in residential areas . The repairing, rebuilding, or testing of any motor vehicle between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. within any residential area in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of the residents of the area. 8. Schools, courts, churches, hospitals . The creating of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church, or court while the same are in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital, or court street. 9. Hawkers and peddlers . The selling of anything by outcry within the residential areas of the town, except at licensed sporting events, parades, fairs, circuses, and other similar licensed public entertainment events. 10. Drums . The using of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by the creation of noise within the town, unless a permit for such use has been obtained from the mayor or chief of police. 11. Other . Conduct which causes substantial discomfort or annoyance to persons of normal sensitiveness or endangers the comfort, repose, health, or peace of the residents of the Town of Thunderbolt. (Council, 6/12/1986). Sec. 10-503. - Exemptions. The following uses and activities shall be exempt from the noise regulations set forth in this chapter: 1. Noises of safety signals and warning devices; 2. Noises resulting from any authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or acting in a time of emergency; and 3. Noises resulting from emergency work, to be construed as work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. (Council, 02/12/1986). Sec. 10-504. - Penalty. Breach of sections 10-501 through 10-502 are punishable by a maximum fine of: $150.00 First offense, plus six months' probation. $250.00 Second offense, plus six months' probation. $1,000.00 Third offense, plus six months' probation. ARTICLE VI. - NUISANCES IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-601. - Complaint Initiation. Proceedings to abate a nuisance other than the specific conditions found in articles III, IV, and VIII of this chapter whether public or private, shall be initiated by the filing of a complaint with the town clerk, which such complaint shall state the nature and location of the nuisance and the name and address of the complainant or complainants. In the case of a private nuisance, the complaint shall be filed by the person or person injured by the nuisance; in the case of a public nuisance, the complaint shall be filed on behalf of the public by a town official or by a citizen specially injured by the nuisance (Council, 02/12/1986, revised 01/09/2008.) Sec. 10-602. - Notice to alleged violator.
